results.title: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
Rosalie Kunoth-Monks: Aboriginal activist, actor, social worker, Parliamentary Candidate 1979-1981, President Aboriginal Legal Aid NT 1983-87, 1990-93, was born in Utopia, Central Australia, 1937 and is of German Aboriginal parentage. Kunoth-Monks discusses her education at St Mary’s Children’s Hostel, Alice Springs, and on being discovered by Charles and Elsa Chauvel as the lead in “Jedda”. She talks about working on the film, and her family’s response to it, in particular the sexual references. A greater passion was to help people, and Rosalie joined the Community of the Holy Name in Melbourne and was a nun for ten years, also gaining training during this period in childcare. Working as an Aboriginal liaison officer in Victoria after leaving the sisterhood, Kunoth-Monks also established the first Aboriginal Family Group home, in addition to marrying during this period. A return to Central Australia saw her working for the Country Liberal Party and being active in social welfare before she returned, full circle, to Utopia.

results.title: Graeme Bell
results.creator_credit: Frank Heimans, Sharon Connolly and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
Often described as the ‘father of Australian jazz’ Graeme Bell has had a sixty year love affair with music, both as a performer and a composer. Discover the story of his life, speak to the man about his passion, and hear his wonderful music.

results.title: Sheep's back
results.creator_credit: Peter Butt, Susan Ardill and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Australia rode on the sheep’s back for over a century. Wool and the people who grew it became entwined with our national identity and the image of the sheep adorned postage stamps and coinage. The Country Party was a powerful force in Australian politics, however by the 1960’s it was Australia’s mineral deposits, particularly iron ore which began to dominate trade. As a consequence, rural Australians found themselves out of step with Australians living in our rapidly changing cities. This excellent documentary looks at the history of wool and examines what the future holds for those Australians who once rode upon the sheep’s back.

results.title: Populate or perish
results.brief_description: Explores Australia’s population debate showing how after 50 years of continuous growth, new arguments about limiting Australia’s population are emerging. This program examines the post-war era when the cry to “Populate or perish” fostered Government sponsored immigration shemes, provided the applicants were white. It traces the gradual evolution of Australia as a multicultural society, primarily concentrated on the east coast.

results.title: Land of the long weekend
results.creator_credit: Sue Brooks, Susan Ardill and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Australia was the first country in the world to have a 40 hour working week, which accompanied by an array of public holidays, led to the identification of Australia as the working man’s paradise, a mythical land of the long weekend. This film examines how, in the face of deregulation and restructuring, long term unemployment and 24 hour trading, Australians have structured and restructured their time. Will Australians, drunk on sunshine, rally in time to save their precious weekend - or has it, in the drive to be flexible and efficient, already been lost?

results.title: Anywhere and here [installation suite]
results.brief_description:
‘anywhere and here’ is a suite of five interconnected kinetic sculptures which generate their own real-time video. It specifically explores the road movie genre, summoning familiar visions of the empty landscape, the wide open road and the car-in-motion, to destabilise powerful cinematic clichés.

‘anywhere and here’ was commissioned by ACMI and was exhibited at ACMI as “Ian Burns: In the Telling” in 2012-13.

Burns adapts existing appliances and domestic items and gives them new functions within his sculptures. This work draws meaning from the contrast between the projected image and the machinery out of which it is made.

The five sculptures that make up this work are linked via a video control system constructed by Burns and designed to switch between each of the structures at random. The images that are produced by the sculptures are projected onto the wall for the audience to view. Each scene generates its own live soundtrack. Burns has hacked an electronic keyboard to plunk out a simple music track. The keyboard becomes an integral part of the sculpture.

A shot of the moon suspended over water is based around a glass top table. The resulting optic effect simulates water movement and sparkle. A strip of plywood simulates the sky at dusk, while the moon is created by the projection of light through a hole in the wood.

On one end of a folding table the effect of a smoking chimney is generated using a plastic salad bowl with a LED light inside shining through a slit cut in the backing of a picture frame. The view from the camera is across a roll of hobby store brick print paper.

On the other end of the folding table, to simulate a high zoom shot of a plane passing overhead, Burns rotates a party store plastic salad bowl while a LED light inside the bowl generates the cloud effect. A fan usually used as a cooling device for a computer, generates the sound of the jet and shakes the camera to simulate the zoom effect on a hand-held camera.

A black vinyl chair has been stripped of all its vinyl until only a narrowing strip remains with slots cut out of it. The camera view of this under a red light gives it the look of a remote roadway in dry country.

The shot in close-up of a wheel with the white stripes of the road whizzing past is a road movie cliché. The sculpture is constructed out of an actual car wheel on a treadmill and a camera positioned to catch a cinematic view of the action.

The fifth sculpture comprises the central electronic system that guides the work as a whole.

results.title: Stereo Sequences [installation suite]
results.brief_description:
A suite of five moving image installations created for the exhibition ‘Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences’.
Filmed in Australia – in a disused mining tunnel in the Wollemi National Park, the dusty highways of Broken Hill, the lush foreshores and wetlands of Victoria’s east coast and the subterranean underpasses of inner city Sydney – this suite of works plays with concepts of duality, parallels and mirroring.

results.title: Track and Trails [installation]
results.material_description: 2 channel video, projection, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
One of a suite of five moving image installations created for the exhibition ‘Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences’.

The two channel installation ‘Track and Trails’ sets up a relationship between two opposing screens. One features footage of track riding under the Sydney Harbour Bridge (track riding is a fixed, single gear, break-less style of bicycle riding that was developed in the velodrome but made popular by couriers in New York City in the late 1990s). The second features trail bike riding (a competitive off-road, all-terrain practice that also uses fixed gear bicycles) on a rocky ocean foreshore.

results.title: Sagittarius / Domain + Prelude [installation]
results.material_description: 2 channel video, projection, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
One of a suite of five moving image installations created for the exhibition ‘Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences’.

‘Sagittarius/Domain + Prelude’ sits in an enclosed room, two screens facing each other on opposite walls. In both, a lone figure tracked from behind – the camera employing a classical point of view, mimicking the work of Caspar David Friedrich – descends into a subterranean passageway. For the viewer these figures act like avatars, our perspective being theirs, one moment behind.
